node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.text:
In America, black people are almost twice more likely to die from covid-19 as white people. Our journalists explain how the pandemic has illuminated systemic racism in America. 

Cover image credit: Getty Images

node.title: How covid-19 exposes systemic racism in America

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 12, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'SUPPORT amazon WORKERS RETIREE'.

node.text:
Since the 1980s, politicians have been freeing up one side of the labour market in the name of competition—by restricting the power of trade unions—but doing very little about the power of firms. ⁠
⁠
President Joe Biden has now sworn to tackle this lack of competition which he says is squashing wages for workers. ⁠
⁠
When there are few employers competing for workers, this is known as “monopsony power”. In these circumstances, firms can collude and make it harder for workers to move, apply for new jobs and relocate. ⁠
⁠
An estimated one in five jobs in America now is covered by a “non-compete” clause, which restricts the rights of workers to move to rival firms. Mr Biden says this has been done for “one reason: to keep wages low.”⁠
⁠
But are workers really getting a raw deal? Click the link in our bio to find out.⁠
⁠
Pic credit: Alamy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 12, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Business The Olympics is a ratings flop. Advertisers don't care R REPUSEC'.

node.text:
Did you watch the Olympic games each night? You may be in the minority. ⁠
⁠
In America just 15.5m people did so, the fewest since NBCUniversal began covering the event in 1988. Broadcasters in Europe recorded similar falls. ⁠
⁠
NBC scrambled to offer brands free spots to make up for the ratings shortfall.⁠
⁠
Yet the Tokyo games illustrate a puzzle: even as audiences decline, the TV-ad market is holding up. Will it last? To find out, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Reuters/Edgard Garrido

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 12, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'United States Joe Biden's splurge on infrastructure moves a step closer'.

node.text:
If Joe Biden's infrastructure plan comes to fruition, it will probably become the defining accomplishment of his presidency.⁠
⁠
It is remarkable that, if he gets his way, he could sign legislation authorising the spending of just under $6trn, almost 30% of GDP, in his first year in office.⁠
⁠
Mr Biden has pulled off a surprising victory in the bipartisan campaign. But now the partisan battle promises to be every bit as arduous.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to learn how the White House has made greater headway than many expected.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @klawerzeczy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 12, 2021. May be a cartoon of ‎text that says '‎The Economist Can fghanistan be saved? Timeto travel restrictions The IPCC's methane Our German election model AUGUST China's attack on tech اון 美团夫心‎'‎.

node.text:
China’s assault on its $4trn tech industry is startling—and risky.⁠
⁠
Regulators have mounted over 50 regulatory actions against scores of firms. The threat of government action has weighed on share prices, costing investors $900bn.⁠
⁠
Xi Jingping’s immediate goal may be to humble tycoons and give regulators more power. But the Communist Party’s deeper ambition is to redesign the industry.⁠
⁠
A world-beating tech industry could be the foundation for China to challenge to American supremacy. So why is the government clipping its wings?⁠
⁠
Click the link on our bio to read our cover this week, which argues that China’s tech clampdown is likely to prove self-defeating.⁠
⁠
Credit: @guillemcasasus

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 12, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Demand for air conditioning is set to surge by 2050 Air-conditioning use in households, % of total* By income tercile Nigeria 100 75 95% confidence interval 50 2010 25 20 30 High Medium Low 50 40 0 *Estimate 2010-21, forecast from 2022 Source: "Air conditioninga global inequality", by Davis et al., Global Environmental Change, 2021 The Economist'.

node.text:
Just 8% of the 2.8bn people living in the hottest parts of the world owned air conditioning units five years ago. That proportion is expected to increase rapidly.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Researchers predicted that the percentage of households with air conditioning across 16 countries, including America, China, India, Nigeria and Pakistan, would rise from an average of 35% in 2020 to 55% in 2050.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Researchers found that the use of AC itself contributes to global warming, making life even hotter for everyone. And it is not just the environment which will suffer. Increasing use of AC could have social and political effects, too.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click on the link on our bio to read why rising temperatures are not the only reason people are turning on their air conditioning.

Photo by The Economist on August 12, 2021. May be an image of standing, outdoors and text that says 'Leaders It might still be possible to save Afghanistan. But America is refusing to try'.

node.text:
The Taliban’s takeover of Afghanistan is growing ever more likely by the day—in large part because America is doing too little to help.⁠
⁠
Ideally, America would not be withdrawing its forces from Afghanistan at all. For several years, with only a few thousand troops who sustained few casualties, it had managed to maintain a stalemate between the Afghan government and the Taliban, thanks largely to air power. ⁠
⁠
Yet last year, when Donald Trump was president, America struck a deal with the Taliban. Mr Trump wanted a quick end to the 20-year deployment, and Joe Biden has stuck by that callous decision.⁠
⁠
America’s rush for the exit has allowed the Taliban to drop the pretence of negotiations and redouble their campaign to remove the government by force. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read how a revived Taliban emirate will not just abuse Afghans; it will spread misery around the region.⁠
⁠
Credit: AP Photo/Abdullah Sahil⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 11, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Middle East & Africa What another five years of Edgar Lungu would mean for Zambia Paladdo'.

node.text:
Over the six years since Edgar Lungu became Zambia’s president in 2015, the economy has on average grown at a slower rate than the population. ⁠
⁠
Inflation is at its highest level in 19 years and government debt has risen from 34% to 110% of GDP under Mr Lungu. ⁠
⁠
Tomorrow Zambians will vote in a pivotal election. And although polls suggest that Mr Lungu is unpopular, it is uncertain whether his time is up.⁠
⁠
In recent years many incumbent African presidents have used the power of the state to buy off or bully voters. Mr Lungu’s party seems to be doing the same in Zambia, one of the ﬁrst African countries to embrace multi-party democracy.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read why hostility to business and impunity for graft would continue if Mr Lungu remains in power. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Britta Pedersen/Alamy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 11, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Books & arts What is "cultish" language and how can words bind people to to organisations?'.

node.text:
What do Scientology members, “boss babes” and supporters of QAnon have in common?⁠
⁠
In her new book, “Cultish”, Amanda Montell explores how a unique use of language can join groups together, and give people a powerful sense of belonging.⁠
⁠
She also addresses the question of whether being made to use a certain vocabulary makes people manipulative.⁠
⁠
The book moves through modern belief systems to multilevel marketing organisations, whose members are often put under pressure not only to sell products but to recruit new associates.⁠
⁠
To read what makes cultish vocabulary so effective, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @nicklowndes_illustrator

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 11, 2021. May be an image of car and text that says 'Finance & economics America's inflation scare becomes less menacing 7614 FRANK adillac SUNSE CORRENTE CORNER 3)850-18'.

node.text:
The depictions of used-car salesmen in American culture are unfair to most of the hard-working types on car lots. But in recent months they have occupied a distinctive and unflattering place in America’s economy, as avatars of worryingly rapid inflation.⁠
⁠
When consumer prices rose by 5.4% in June compared with a year earlier, the fastest pace since 2008, used cars accounted for a third of the pickup. So analysts are paying unusually close attention to the market for used cars (or, as those selling them prefer to say, “pre-owned” vehicles). ⁠
⁠
On August 11th the Bureau of Labour Statistics reported that annual headline inflation in July again hit 5.4%. ⁠
⁠
But when you look under the hood, the gauge for used cars offers reassurance: prices levelled off, suggesting that the inflation scare may prove transitory. Click the link in our bio to find out why.

Credit: Alamy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'By Invitation How responses to the pandemic helped people sleeping rough Covid-19 brought a small light of progress'.

node.text:
“An intriguing outcome of covid-19 is that it almost immediately ended rough sleeping for tens of thousands of people," argues Linda Gibbs, a former New York City official, in The Economist.⁠
⁠
When lockdowns began in 2020, officials in America and elsewhere feared that people living on the street would become a source of concentrated infection. Instead of sheltering them in large centres, such as gymnasiums or stadiums, they needed to be in separate rooms to prevent the spread of disease. What transpired was officials quickly devising ways to get rough sleepers into the vast inventory of vacant hotel rooms at public expense, writes Ms Gibbs. ⁠
⁠
Yet the accommodations for homeless people were temporary. Could there be ways to keep them off the street permanently?⁠
⁠
“The pandemic and lockdown have been a horrible experience for most people around the world. But for those who had long been sleeping on the street, a small light of progress flickers,” she argues. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read Linda Gibbs’s full article, and to learn why the pandemic exposed new strategies of support for people sleeping rough.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Britain British farmers are being targeted by cyber-criminals'.

node.text:
At the top of British farmers' concerns about crime: sheep-rustling, fly-tipping and livestock-worrying. What about cybersecurity?⁠
⁠
Many farmers neglect cyber-risks. But online fraud is coming to the British countryside. ⁠
⁠
Phishing emails about farming-­subsidy payments are becoming more common, and people are falling for scams advertising expensive tractors. ⁠
⁠
One reason rural crime is going virtual is that farming is increasingly automated, from gate­-opening and tractor­-driving to cow­-milking. ⁠
⁠
But tap the link in our bio to read how little is being offered in the way of solutions to crack down on it. ⁠
⁠
Credit: @lo_cole

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The links between the crypto-sphere and mainstream markets are growing Cryptocurrencies, trading volume, $bn By size of trade "Institutional" $1m or more "Professional" $10,000-$1m "Retail" Less than $10,000 150 120 90 60 2017 30 18 Source: Chainalysis 19 20 21 The Economist'.

node.text:
The crypto-universe is expanding—rapidly.⁠
⁠
Today the combined market capitalisation of all 11,145 crypto currencies is roughly equivalent to the nominal GDP of Canada.⁠
⁠
Crypto investors have become more sophisticated and deep-pocketed, too. As this chart shows, institutions account for 63% of trading, up from 10% in 2017.⁠
⁠
This maturing, however, has failed to tame the wild gyrations that characterise crypto markets.⁠
⁠
Every downward lurch raises the question of how bad the fallout might be. Too much seems at stake for the cryptocurrency to collapse.⁠
⁠
But what if it did? Click on the link in our bio to read a hypothetical situation in which we imagine that the price of bitcoin crashes all the way to zero.
